MANY CANDIDATES AT MEETING

RETURNS FROM TREATY REFERENDUM.

Captain Bartels, Coaches and 'Varsity
Club Representatives Speak at
Track Organization Practice
Started at Homewood.

• Advocates of ratification of the peace treaty by compromise headed
the poll in the complete returns of the intercollegiate referendum,
which were made public in New York Saturday night. Those who favored ratification without reservation or amendment led by a small
majority.
According to the revised figures, the referendum was voted upon in
410 colleges and universities, and 139,788 votes were cast, with the following results:

The track organization meeting
was held in the Civil Engineering
Lecture Hall, Monday, January
12. Captain Bartels, in opening
the meeting, expressed his appreciation of the large number that
attended and urged the new men
to come out for the squad. He
explained that the new men would
have greater opportunities this
year for winning their "H" in
track than in any other sport, owing to the scarcity of last year's
letter men.
Mr. England, a former Hopkins
track star and for many years a
coach of the Hopkins team, spoke
at the meeting about the plans for
the coining year and of the hard
work ahead, necessary to carry
The schedule,
them tlirough.
which will be 101111(1 at the end of
this article, is the largest and
hardest ever attempted by the
track team. It will necessitate
the continuous training of the
squad for over four months, something which has never been done
before at Hopkins.' However, as
Mr. England pointed out, with
such a large squad to start with,
a very successful team should be
developed.
Mr. Lloyd, who was also a brilliant track man at Hopkins and
who has aided Mr. England in
coaching the team, addressed the
meeting, emphasizing the points
brought out by Mr. England and

HOPKINS DEFEATS LEHIGH
Close Contest Won by Score of 36-32
Swimming Management Hopes to Organize a Middle State Intercollegiate Swimming Association.

The Johns Hopkins swimming
team opened its season most successfully by defeating the Lehigh
team in a very close and exciting
meet at the Baltimore Athletic
Club on January 10. The contest
was not decided iiimtil the results
of the fancy diving were an1101111Ced at the end. Had Lehigh
been awarded the two first places
in this event, she would have been
winner by two points. As it happened, however, Hopkins' (livers
gained second and third and
Thue
won by the score of
meet was one of the most thrilling
witnessed at the Baltimore Athletic Club for sonic I lute, as every
event except the relay, in which
.Hopkins lead from the start, was
so • closely contested that the spectators were kept on their feet for
most of the time.
Reins, Johnston, Hall and D.
Rowland, representing Hopkins in
the 160-yard relay, the opening
event, had little difficulty in defeating their opponents. Rosenmiller and Daniami, of Lehigh,
carried off first and second places,
respectively, in the plunge. Davidge Rowland won the 40-yard
dash, with two Lehigh men close
behind him. "Bob" Hall, Hopkins' captain, created sonic excitement by a sensational spurt in the
last lap of the 220 yards. but lost
by inches to Jacobs, of Lehigh.
Stewart, of the visitors, was adjudged winner of the fancy divincr,
Slingluff followed, and Call, who
deserves credit for his conscientious work all this year, won third
place. Stewart, of Lehigh, won
the 40-yard breast-stroke from Da• vidge Rowland in a very close
race. Reins and Hall finished first
and second in the back-stroke, and
Henry Rowland first in the 100yard swim.
Although a few of the men practiced individually on Monday and
Tuesday after the meet, no regular
practice was held until Thursday
night. Coach Ortland was present and put the men through their
paces and also pointed out some
of the faults shown (luring the
Lehigh contest. The absence of
"Bill" Reins, one of the stars of
the team, is sure to be seriously
felt. "Bill" strained one of the muscles in his thigh a week or so ago
and then caught cold. Although
he won the back-stroke and swam
on the victorious relay team in the
meet, this was accomplished only
by a severe strain upon himself,

BALTIMORE, MD.,

JAN. 20, 1920

Fair Play or None at All.

It has been rumored around
that Hopkins was going to resort
to the dispensing of "football
scholarships" to aid in the turning out of a winning team. Every
possible source for such a fabrication was investigated by THE
NEW S-LETTER, but nothing could
be found to substantiate it. Such
rot must, therefore, be a pernicious figment of a perverted imagination.
The very face of such an idea
is false and ridiculous. True, we
have slumped a little in football
the last few years—it would be
contrary to every law of nature
for a team to win all the time.
But we have carried off State
championships in the past, when
Hopkins was an infant in size in
comparison with what it is today
Mid what it will be in the near
future, when our enrollment will
be trebled and more through the
natural impetus given to undergraduate life as a result of students living together in a dormitory on the campus. We have won
in the past and we shall win in
the days to come, and those victories will c(ane to us without once
lowering (mi. standards of fair
Play.
No true Hopkins man would
harbor any other thoughts than
those of clean sportsmanship. In
planning for a bigger and better
Hopkins, the 'Varsity Club, composed of only the most loyal of
our alumni, has considered the
possibility of offering to preparatory school graduates who desire
to enter Hopkins a few scholar-

ships, the examination being of

To the Editor Of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—I am writing to ask the cooperation of the seniors in making
the Hullabaloo a success. About
a month ago, a circular letter was
sent out requesting that each senior submit to the art editor a snapshot of himself taken while in
some characteristic pose, and information as to the general size of
this photo and its finish, was contained therein. For the information of those who have overlooked
this important matter, the :size of
the desired "snap" should be

make the 1920 Hullabaloo the

your own albums and your friends'

Echoes Disturb His Steps.
To the Editor Of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Sir—I simply want to offer my
congratulations to the Cotillion
Board for the splendid manner in
which the informal dance was
"pulled off" after the basket-ball
game Friday night. Everybody
seemed to enjoy it immensely,
both Hopkins men and outsiders,
and the only bit of criticism that
would 'possibly be made was concerning the band. -It seems to me
that it would have been better if
the committee had engaged a small
orchestra, because the music of the
band vibrated so throughout the
large armory that it was rather
difficult to keep in step. This is
merely a suggestion, but as a good
many (lancers found this same
fault, I thought a change might
be effected in the future.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—T should like to use some
of your valuable space in order to
file a .protest against the promiscuous eating of lunches about Gilman Hall and in the student massmeetings.
It is not a pleasant sight that
greets the eyes when one enters
the basement door of Gilman Hall.
and sees college students flitting

NATURALISTS' CLUB ACTIVE

CLOSE CONTEST ENDS IN DEFEAT

AT OTHER COLLEGES
(('ontinued Irani page 2)

lists of birds and other creatures.
The successful effort of the Club
in its early days to make a. field
club map later was followed up
by the deep interest which the
University has always taken in
the map-making of Maryland. As
time went on the interests of the
members in many cases became so
specialized that the Club finally
went to pieces •by giving rise to
purely scientific investigations.
Thus the geologists soon found
that the region round about Baltimore was a subject for profound
and deep study and that superficial acquaintance with it was no
longer sufficient. In the same way;
the botaniSts took up the study of
the plants as part of the regular
post-Oaduate work. While the
zoologists were fortunate enough
to be able to go to the seaside f,
their special work and therefore
neglected the local condition,
more and more.
It has, however, been realized
that with the increased number
of the student body, that both
students from a distance were not
well acquainted with the region
around about Baltimore and students in Baltimore would like to
enlarge and continue their interest in natural history. For the
benefit of both thee classes of
students, it is planned to revive
the old Naturalists' Field Club,
to hold occasional meetings and to
have informal excursions in the
neighborhood of Baltimore. A
preliminary meeting last week indicated that quite a number were
interested in the project. Professor Cowles presented some very
remarkable observations made in
the Philippine Islands on the natural history -of some crabs. The
coming week, December 15,. there
will be communications upon
beetles and lichens at 4 P. M. in
Room 11, Gilman Hall. Thus far
there is no fixed organization, but
it is hoped that all those who are
interested will join the Club to
the extent of giving their names,
being present at some of the meetings and taking part in some of
the excursions.
An excursion on Saturday, December 13, was made to certain
ponds for the purpose of seeing
what minute forms of life could
be found active at this season of
the year when most life is dormant and inactive, apparently. It
is hoped that all those who have
interest in the country for the
pleasure they get out of walks or
who have collected insects or other
forms of life or who would like to
learn something about the collecting and study of various sorts of
plants and animal life in the fields,
waters, and woods, will join the
Club and take active part in the
excursions and bring into the
meetings all questions and objects
upon which some light may be
thrown by other members of the
Club.

(Continuedfrom page I)
Lehigh University.

Lehigh has organized a debating society which hopes to get a
team into shape in time to accept
challenges from other universities
and colleges this year.
George Washington University.

A "Veteran Club" has been
formed as the university's service
organization. It is expected to
play an important and powerful
role in the life of the school and
is heartily backed by the college
authorities.
Laurence College.

The students of the Wisconsin
college were lucky enough to have
their Christmas holidays begin
December 16, owing to a case of
smallpox in one of the dormitories.
The editorial staff of the Laurentian/ is to be congratulated for
the Christmas issite of their weekly, which contained twenty-four
pages of well gotten-up material.
Swarthmore.

The home of four of the college
fraternities was recently destroyed by fire. The chapters
were all housed in one building,
and all but one suffered a total.
loss.
Carnegie Institute of Technology.

Yale has asked for a game with
the Institute for her 1920 football
schedule.
Tufts.

Acting President Cousens, of
Tufts, told the board of the Tufts
Weekly that he believed it the
function of a college paper to expose and condemn those conditions in the college which they
knew existed, but ordinarily did
not mention for fear of hurting
the reputation of the college. He
said that there was a clear line,
however, between condemnation
and muck-raking.
Yale University.

Yale University has established
a "sub-station" in Changsha,
China, which is doing much to
better the lot of the 22,000,000
people of the province of Hunan.
With the aid of the China Medical
Board, Yale also conducts a medical school with a $200,000 hospital, where 125 doctors and
nurses are receiving instruction.
From the first members of the
Club not connected with the University were among its most active
supporters and it is to be desired
that at present people outside the
University will take part in reviving and continuing the Club.
Its primary purpose is to associate those who take pleasure in
nature, and are interested in natural history as an. avocation. •

The remaining time until the
next meet, scheduled with Navy
at Annapolis on January 24, will
be used for "brushing up on form
and increasing the men's endurance.
The swimming management has
undertaken to organize the swimming teams in the colleges in the
neighborhood of Philadelphia,
comprising the Middle Atlantic
States, into an inter-collegiate
swimming association. At present
there is such an organizal ion
among the. large colleges in ilie
North, and it is felt that a combination of colleges from Stevens to
Hopkins and as far west as Pittsburgh would be of great benefit in
promoting the spirit farther south.
Conflicts of schedules would be
avoided and better details in management would be. effected also,
advertisement of the meets could
be controlled centrally if found
advisable.
• Letters have been sent out to
the various colleges in the proposed section of the country, and
if time replies thus far received are
indicative of the general sentiment, Hopkins will have the honor
of having taken the initiative in
establishing an inter-collegiate
swimming association as strong
as any in the country.
Old Familiar Poem.
But yesterday the world was bright,
The sun was flooding all with light,
The Fiky was blue, the air was clear,
It really seemed that Heaven was
near;
Such joy surrounded everything,
It•made me want to laugh and sing;
It made me feel so bright and gay
And glad—but that was yesterday.
And now the sky is dark and drear,
And Heaven seems no longer near;
If I should sing, 'twould be a croon
Set to a doleful minor tune;
For joy has left me, and this life
Seems but a time of toil and strife.
No longer does my heart feel gay—
I had ten dollars yesterday!
—Ex.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 20, 1920.

FINE PROGRAM IN LITERARY CLUB

ALDRED LECTURES ANNOUNCED

Interesting Meeting Held--Hammond
and Goetz Read Papers—Next
Meeting January 23rd.

All Engineering Students Arc Required
to Attend the Lectures on
Engineering Practice.

The Literary Club meeting on
Friday. January 9, was both novel
and instructive. Indeed, it would
have delighted even the hearts of
those who are sufficiently plehian
in taste as to admit that they do
not care at all for poetry, but 'quid
rather hear a dry wheel grate on
the axle-tree; and that would set
our teeth nothing on edge, nothing
so much as mincing poetry." Surely "The Cult of the immediate"
the theme of Mr. Hammond's paper) is anything but "mincing
poetry." Much of it is like the
raucous jazz of the popular ragtime and its reading affords entertainment which some One has
termed higher vaudeville.
Mr. Hammond outlined the romantic revolution in painting, music and poetry and showed how
the distrust ing of generalities and
the desire to get away from intellectualism are flavoring contemporary poetry. He divided the
cult of the immediate into three
groups: First, there is Kreymborg
and his school, whose poetry is
little more than problems in analytical or differential calculus.
Sha,(les of Dr. Hulburt! The second .group attempts to write
poetry which gives primacy to
sound. The chief in this school
are Chesterton„Benet and Lindsay. At this point, Mr. Hammond
lead with all the intonation of
V()ice prescribed by the side notes,
the .delightful poem of Vochel
Lindsay's, called"The Congo."
This poem is a good example of
the higher vaudeville and admirably illustrates the use of symbolism, which some classicist has
termed cymbalism.
The last
group discussed were the imagist s, who number six poets and
have definite rules for verification.
This school gives chief importance
to free verse, and Miss Lowell is
the chief writer of it in this country. This concluded Mr. Ham111011(1'S interesting paper.
Creorge (Ioetz, the second speaker, discussed "Mysticism in Maeterlinck."
In (loetz's opinion,
mysticism is out of place in this
present day world—this world of
scientific research. Maeterlinck,
who is himself a mystic, is not
satisfied with the uncertainty of
science, so he seeks what the mystics term reality or real truth.
The mystic loveliness of Maeterlinck's works were illustrated by
readimrs fr9m his "Treson des
IIu'fibres," "12Intruse," "La Princes,e Moliere" and "Mort de Tintagil."

J. E. Aldred there has been founded in the Department of Engineering a course of lectures on engineering practice. The course of
lectures is one feature of a gem
eral plan, made possible by Mr.
Aldred's gift, for furthering and
improving undergraduate instruction in the methods and problems
of the practice of engineering.
The lectures will deal, therefore,
with the practical phases of engineering problems, rather than
with theory. They are not expected to discuss new and striking applicai ion, as much as to deal with
everyday working methods of design, construction and operation.
Since the lectures are planned
especially for undergraduate students, they will presuppose an elementary rather than an extensive
knowledge Of underlying theory,
and will lay special stress on the
tangible and obvious features and
principles of practical engineering of the present (lay.
During the year 1 91 9-1 920 three
lectures each will be given in the
general subjects: Civil, electrical
and mechanical engineering. They
will be given on Wednesday afternoons at -1.13 o'clock, on the dates
shown below, in the auditorium
of the Civil Engineering Building
of the University, at Homewood.
The requisite number of seats
in the lecture hall will be reserved
for the student body. There will,
however, be ample additional
space, and engineers or others who
may be interested will be welcomed. The lectures are open to
the general public, and tickets of
admission are not required.

HOPKINS DEFEATS LEHIGH
Close Contest Won by Score of 36-32
Swimming Management Hopes to Organize a Middle State Intercollegiate Swimming Association.

The Johns Hopkins swimming
team opened its season most successfully by defeating the Lehigh
team in a very close and exciting
meet at the Baltimore Athletic
Club on January 10. The contest
was not decided iiimtil the results
of the fancy diving were an1101111Ced at the end. Had Lehigh
been awarded the two first places
in this event, she would have been
winner by two points. As it happened, however, Hopkins' (livers
gained second and third and
Thue
won by the score of
meet was one of the most thrilling
witnessed at the Baltimore Athletic Club for sonic I lute, as every
event except the relay, in which
.Hopkins lead from the start, was
so • closely contested that the spectators were kept on their feet for
most of the time.
Reins, Johnston, Hall and D.
Rowland, representing Hopkins in
the 160-yard relay, the opening
event, had little difficulty in defeating their opponents. Rosenmiller and Daniami, of Lehigh,
carried off first and second places,
respectively, in the plunge. Davidge Rowland won the 40-yard
dash, with two Lehigh men close
behind him. "Bob" Hall, Hopkins' captain, created sonic excitement by a sensational spurt in the
last lap of the 220 yards. but lost
by inches to Jacobs, of Lehigh.
Stewart, of the visitors, was adjudged winner of the fancy divincr,
Slingluff followed, and Call, who
deserves credit for his conscientious work all this year, won third
place. Stewart, of Lehigh, won
the 40-yard breast-stroke from Da• vidge Rowland in a very close
race. Reins and Hall finished first
and second in the back-stroke, and
Henry Rowland first in the 100yard swim.
Although a few of the men practiced individually on Monday and
Tuesday after the meet, no regular
practice was held until Thursday
night. Coach Ortland was present and put the men through their
paces and also pointed out some
of the faults shown (luring the
Lehigh contest. The absence of
"Bill" Reins, one of the stars of
the team, is sure to be seriously
felt. "Bill" strained one of the muscles in his thigh a week or so ago
and then caught cold. Although
he won the back-stroke and swam
on the victorious relay team in the
meet, this was accomplished only
by a severe strain upon himself,

Fair Play or None at All.

It has been rumored around
that Hopkins was going to resort
to the dispensing of "football
scholarships" to aid in the turning out of a winning team. Every
possible source for such a fabrication was investigated by THE
NEW S-LETTER, but nothing could
be found to substantiate it. Such
rot must, therefore, be a pernicious figment of a perverted imagination.
The very face of such an idea
is false and ridiculous. True, we
have slumped a little in football
the last few years—it would be
contrary to every law of nature
for a team to win all the time.
But we have carried off State
championships in the past, when
Hopkins was an infant in size in
comparison with what it is today
Mid what it will be in the near
future, when our enrollment will
be trebled and more through the
natural impetus given to undergraduate life as a result of students living together in a dormitory on the campus. We have won
in the past and we shall win in
the days to come, and those victories will c(ane to us without once
lowering (mi. standards of fair
Play.
No true Hopkins man would
harbor any other thoughts than
those of clean sportsmanship. In
planning for a bigger and better
Hopkins, the 'Varsity Club, composed of only the most loyal of
our alumni, has considered the
possibility of offering to preparatory school graduates who desire
to enter Hopkins a few scholar-

ships, the examination being of

Echoes Disturb His Steps.
To the Editor Of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Sir—I simply want to offer my
congratulations to the Cotillion
Board for the splendid manner in
which the informal dance was
"pulled off" after the basket-ball
game Friday night. Everybody
seemed to enjoy it immensely,
both Hopkins men and outsiders,
and the only bit of criticism that
would 'possibly be made was concerning the band. -It seems to me
that it would have been better if
the committee had engaged a small
orchestra, because the music of the
band vibrated so throughout the
large armory that it was rather
difficult to keep in step. This is
merely a suggestion, but as a good
many (lancers found this same
fault, I thought a change might
be effected in the future.

the basement door of Gilman Hall.
and sees college students flitting
about like lost Shades eating .a
sandwich that is held in one hand

NATURALISTS' CLUB ACTIVE

CLOSE CONTEST ENDS IN DEFEAT

AT OTHER COLLEGES
(('ontinued Irani page 2)

lists of birds and other creatures.
The successful effort of the Club
in its early days to make a. field
club map later was followed up
by the deep interest which the
University has always taken in
the map-making of Maryland. As
time went on the interests of the
members in many cases became so
specialized that the Club finally
went to pieces •by giving rise to
purely scientific investigations.
Thus the geologists soon found
that the region round about Baltimore was a subject for profound
and deep study and that superficial acquaintance with it was no
longer sufficient. In the same way;
the botaniSts took up the study of
the plants as part of the regular
post-Oaduate work. While the
zoologists were fortunate enough
to be able to go to the seaside f,
their special work and therefore
neglected the local condition,
more and more.
It has, however, been realized
that with the increased number
of the student body, that both
students from a distance were not
well acquainted with the region
around about Baltimore and students in Baltimore would like to
enlarge and continue their interest in natural history. For the
benefit of both thee classes of
students, it is planned to revive
the old Naturalists' Field Club,
to hold occasional meetings and to
have informal excursions in the
neighborhood of Baltimore. A
preliminary meeting last week indicated that quite a number were
interested in the project. Professor Cowles presented some very
remarkable observations made in
the Philippine Islands on the natural history -of some crabs. The
coming week, December 15,. there
will be communications upon
beetles and lichens at 4 P. M. in
Room 11, Gilman Hall. Thus far
there is no fixed organization, but
it is hoped that all those who are
interested will join the Club to
the extent of giving their names,
being present at some of the meetings and taking part in some of
the excursions.
An excursion on Saturday, December 13, was made to certain
ponds for the purpose of seeing
what minute forms of life could
be found active at this season of
the year when most life is dormant and inactive, apparently. It
is hoped that all those who have
interest in the country for the
pleasure they get out of walks or
who have collected insects or other
forms of life or who would like to
learn something about the collecting and study of various sorts of
plants and animal life in the fields,
waters, and woods, will join the
Club and take active part in the
excursions and bring into the
meetings all questions and objects
upon which some light may be
thrown by other members of the
Club.

(Continuedfrom page I)
Lehigh University.

Lehigh has organized a debating society which hopes to get a
team into shape in time to accept
challenges from other universities
and colleges this year.
George Washington University.

A "Veteran Club" has been
formed as the university's service
organization. It is expected to
play an important and powerful
role in the life of the school and
is heartily backed by the college
authorities.
Laurence College.

The students of the Wisconsin
college were lucky enough to have
their Christmas holidays begin
December 16, owing to a case of
smallpox in one of the dormitories.
The editorial staff of the Laurentian/ is to be congratulated for
the Christmas issite of their weekly, which contained twenty-four
pages of well gotten-up material.
Swarthmore.

The home of four of the college
fraternities was recently destroyed by fire. The chapters
were all housed in one building,
and all but one suffered a total.
loss.
Carnegie Institute of Technology.

Yale has asked for a game with
the Institute for her 1920 football
schedule.
Tufts.

Acting President Cousens, of
Tufts, told the board of the Tufts
Weekly that he believed it the
function of a college paper to expose and condemn those conditions in the college which they
knew existed, but ordinarily did
not mention for fear of hurting
the reputation of the college. He
said that there was a clear line,
however, between condemnation
and muck-raking.
Yale University.

Yale University has established
a "sub-station" in Changsha,
China, which is doing much to
better the lot of the 22,000,000
people of the province of Hunan.
With the aid of the China Medical
Board, Yale also conducts a medical school with a $200,000 hospital, where 125 doctors and
nurses are receiving instruction.
From the first members of the
Club not connected with the University were among its most active
supporters and it is to be desired
that at present people outside the
University will take part in reviving and continuing the Club.
Its primary purpose is to associate those who take pleasure in
nature, and are interested in natural history as an. avocation. •

who scored four of the five, while

had no effect, as the Black and

goal line, and the ball was given

opponent, received the leather

neatly in the basket. Then Weinart got a long distance shot, the

evening, although he had tried unsuccessfully several times before.

of the same variety, and then a
foul put Hopkins temporarily out
of her stride. Baker, however,
failed to get the goal, but Bream
put the ball in immediately afterward. Weinart got another long

dropping in a foul.
Then came a clinch between

he jump Kennady tapped the ball
into the goal. Bream again, tied
the score and Hopkins once more
forged ahead, but just before the
whistle, Baker netted a basket and
the score was tied.
In the last minute of the extra
period Baker succeeded in putting
the ball in the basket on a foul,
and lime visitors trotted off the
floor with the spoils.

The swimming management has
undertaken to organize the swimming teams in the colleges in the
neighborhood of Philadelphia,
comprising the Middle Atlantic
States, into an inter-collegiate
swimming association. At present
there is such an organizal ion
among the. large colleges in ilie
North, and it is felt that a combination of colleges from Stevens to
Hopkins and as far west as Pittsburgh would be of great benefit in
promoting the spirit farther south.
Conflicts of schedules would be
avoided and better details in management would be. effected also,
advertisement of the meets could
be controlled centrally if found
advisable.
• Letters have been sent out to
the various colleges in the proposed section of the country, and
if time replies thus far received are
indicative of the general sentiment, Hopkins will have the honor
of having taken the initiative in
establishing an inter-collegiate
swimming association as strong
as any in the country.
Old Familiar Poem.
But yesterday the world was bright,
The sun was flooding all with light,
The Fiky was blue, the air was clear,
It really seemed that Heaven was
near;
Such joy surrounded everything,
It•made me want to laugh and sing;
It made me feel so bright and gay
And glad—but that was yesterday.
And now the sky is dark and drear,
And Heaven seems no longer near;
If I should sing, 'twould be a croon
Set to a doleful minor tune;
For joy has left me, and this life
Seems but a time of toil and strife.
No longer does my heart feel gay—
I had ten dollars yesterday!
—Ex.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 20, 1920.

FINE PROGRAM IN LITERARY CLUB

ALDRED LECTURES ANNOUNCED

Interesting Meeting Held--Hammond
and Goetz Read Papers—Next
Meeting January 23rd.

All Engineering Students Arc Required
to Attend the Lectures on
Engineering Practice.

The Literary Club meeting on
Friday. January 9, was both novel
and instructive. Indeed, it would
have delighted even the hearts of
those who are sufficiently plehian
in taste as to admit that they do
not care at all for poetry, but 'quid
rather hear a dry wheel grate on
the axle-tree; and that would set
our teeth nothing on edge, nothing
so much as mincing poetry." Surely "The Cult of the immediate"
the theme of Mr. Hammond's paper) is anything but "mincing
poetry." Much of it is like the
raucous jazz of the popular ragtime and its reading affords entertainment which some One has
termed higher vaudeville.
Mr. Hammond outlined the romantic revolution in painting, music and poetry and showed how
the distrust ing of generalities and
the desire to get away from intellectualism are flavoring contemporary poetry. He divided the
cult of the immediate into three
groups: First, there is Kreymborg
and his school, whose poetry is
little more than problems in analytical or differential calculus.
Sha,(les of Dr. Hulburt! The second .group attempts to write
poetry which gives primacy to
sound. The chief in this school
are Chesterton„Benet and Lindsay. At this point, Mr. Hammond
lead with all the intonation of
V()ice prescribed by the side notes,
the .delightful poem of Vochel
Lindsay's, called"The Congo."
This poem is a good example of
the higher vaudeville and admirably illustrates the use of symbolism, which some classicist has
termed cymbalism.
The last
group discussed were the imagist s, who number six poets and
have definite rules for verification.
This school gives chief importance
to free verse, and Miss Lowell is
the chief writer of it in this country. This concluded Mr. Ham111011(1'S interesting paper.
Creorge (Ioetz, the second speaker, discussed "Mysticism in Maeterlinck."
In (loetz's opinion,
mysticism is out of place in this
present day world—this world of
scientific research. Maeterlinck,
who is himself a mystic, is not
satisfied with the uncertainty of
science, so he seeks what the mystics term reality or real truth.
The mystic loveliness of Maeterlinck's works were illustrated by
readimrs fr9m his "Treson des
IIu'fibres," "12Intruse," "La Princes,e Moliere" and "Mort de Tintagil."
Tlw paper was characterized by
delivery
(ioetz's usual an
and ability for drawing sparkling
words ito

J. E. Aldred there has been founded in the Department of Engineering a course of lectures on engineering practice. The course of
lectures is one feature of a gem
eral plan, made possible by Mr.
Aldred's gift, for furthering and
improving undergraduate instruction in the methods and problems
of the practice of engineering.
The lectures will deal, therefore,
with the practical phases of engineering problems, rather than
with theory. They are not expected to discuss new and striking applicai ion, as much as to deal with
everyday working methods of design, construction and operation.
Since the lectures are planned
especially for undergraduate students, they will presuppose an elementary rather than an extensive
knowledge Of underlying theory,
and will lay special stress on the
tangible and obvious features and
principles of practical engineering of the present (lay.
During the year 1 91 9-1 920 three
lectures each will be given in the
general subjects: Civil, electrical
and mechanical engineering. They
will be given on Wednesday afternoons at -1.13 o'clock, on the dates
shown below, in the auditorium
of the Civil Engineering Building
of the University, at Homewood.
The requisite number of seats
in the lecture hall will be reserved
for the student body. There will,
however, be ample additional
space, and engineers or others who
may be interested will be welcomed. The lectures are open to
the general public, and tickets of
admission are not required.
The lectures are on the follOwlug dates:
January 28—"Common Sense in
Engineering," Mr. J. E. Aldred,
4NPAN- York City.
February 11 — "The Development of Long Distance Electric
Power Transmission," Mr. P. M.
Lincoln, consulting engineer,
Cleveland, Ohio.
February 18—"The Purchase
and Erection of Engineering
Equipment," Mr. A. S. Loizeaux,
electrical engineer, Consolidated
Gas Electric Light and Power
Company, Baltimore, Md.
February 25—"City Planning
and Its _Relation to Municipal
I hivelopment," Mr. Nelson P.
Lewis, chief engineer, Board of
Estimate and Apportionment,
New York City.

Approximately 85 scientists atten(led the thirty-seventh annual
meeting of the American Society
of Naturalists, which was held at
Pm iiceton Universit y, December
30 and :11 last. Prof. Caswell
Grave was elected vice-president
of the society for the ensuing year.
Professor Berry, of the Geological I)epartment, has just installed
U series, of small models representing restorations of a dozen different forms of Mesozoic Dinosaurs.
This great group of extinct reptiles furnishes some of the largest
and most bizarre forms of life that
are known during the past history of the earth. North American rocks have probably furnished
a greater variety of these creatures in a. better state of preservation than all the other continents- together. Several mummified forms have been found in old
awatnp deposits in our Western
States with details of skin ornamentation exquisitely preserved.
Fragmentary bones and teeth
have been found in Prince
George's County, Maryland.
